They were ridden barebacked, the German regardinga saddle as a sign of effeminacy (iv. a, 5 4). They were rather means of locomotion than aids in actual fighting. For, when serious work had to be done, the rider would dismount atid stab his opponent's horse under him, tntsting to find his own trained ’ animal waiting for him on his return (iv. 2, ξ 3; 12, ξ a).
